questions.text: A psychiatric patient was started on lithium for the management of bipolar disorder. To monitor the blood lithium levels, at what time interval should the blood sample be collected after the administration of lithium tablets?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - After 12 hou

questions.text: Which medication could potentially cause constipation, blurred vision, and dry mouth in a 70-year-old patient with a history of schizophrenia receiving treatment for drug-induced Parkinson's disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Benzh

Drug Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Anticholinergic

Benzhexol, Trihexyphenidyl, Biperiden

Blockade of muscarinic receptors in the basal ganglia

Dopamine agonist

Pramipexole, Ropinirole

Direct stimulation of dopamine receptors

Beta-blocker

Propranolol

Blockade of beta-receptors in the brain

GABA agonist

Baclofen

Enhancement of GABA-mediated inhibition in the CNS

Amantadine

Amantadine

Enhancement of dopamine release and inhibition of reuptake

Vitamins

Vitamin E

An antioxidant effect that may reduce oxidative damage in the CNS

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding memantine? Its therapeutic effect is due to its action on NMDA It is reserved for moderate to severe diseases. It is used as monotherapy and should not be used with other cholinesterase inhibitors . It is given at a daily dose of 1- 30 mg / day.
questions.explanation:
Memantine

Drug Class

NMDA (N-Methyl-D-Aspartate) Receptor Antagonist

MOA
  • NMDA receptor antagonist: Memantine works by blocking NMDA receptors (which are glutamate receptors) in the brain.
  • Modulates glutamate activity without completely blocking it, reducing excessive glutamatergic neurotransmission that can lead to neurotoxicity in Alzheimer's disease.

Indications
  • Alzheimer's Disease (moderate to severe stage)
  • Dementia

Side Effects

Headache, Dizziness

Contraindications
  • Hypersensitivity to memantine or any of its components
  • Used with caution in renal impairment due to the drug's renal elimination.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is more commonly seen with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine?
questions.explanation:
Adverse effects of Carbamazepine

Adverse Effects

Description

Neurotoxicity

Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia

Gastrointestinal Effects

Vomiting and diarrhoea occur with higher doses.

Acute Intoxication

Coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse.

Haematological

Agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia.

Hypersensitivity Reactions

Rashes (Option C), photosensitivity, hepatitis, lupus-like syndrome.

Water Retention and Hyponatremia

Due to enhanced antidiuretic hormone (ADH) action, it is more common in the elderly.

Teratogenicity

Increased incidence of minor fetal malformations.

Hepatic function

(Option D)

It is associated with elevated levels of gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)-liver enzymes

Hypotension

(Option A)
  • It can cause hypotension, particularly orthostatic hypotension, due to its CNS depressant effects, it is not very common.
  • Oxcarbazepine, although structurally similar, tends to have a lower incidence of hypotension.

questions.text: A patient is brought with altered sensorium and seizures. The attendant showed the laboratory report, which revealed elevated transaminases. Which of the following can be used in this condition?
Which of the following is false regarding disulfiram? Does not stop cravings Accumulates acetaldehyde Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase Maintenance dose is 250 mg

options.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine

options.label: B
options.text: It cannot be reversed by levallorphan

options.label: C
options.text: It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: Tolerance develops due to long-term use

questions.correct_answer: C. It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus
questions.explanation:
Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote)

↓

Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine

↓

Abstinence (Prevent relapse):

  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

options.text: High intrinsic activity, high affinity for D2 receptor, less extrapyramidal symptoms, and less weight gain

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressant drugs acts by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Venlafaxine

Class

Examples

SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors)
  • Fluoxetine (Option A)
  • Paroxetine (Option C)
  • Sertralin
  • Citalopram
  • Escitalopram
  • Dapoxetine (Option D)

SNRI (Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors)
  • Venlafaxine
  • Duloxetine
  • Desvenlafaxine
  • Milnacipran

TCA (Tricyclic Antidepressants)
  • Amitriptyline
  • Nortriptyline
  • Imipramine
  • Clomipramine

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for the condition observed in a 55-year-old male who presents with rigidity, frequent falls, slowness in movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - D

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone?
questions.explanation:
Risperidone

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is approved by the FDA for the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder (both manic and mixed episodes)

MOA

Antagonism at D2 and 5 HT2 receptors

Also binds alpha 1 and 2 receptor, and the H1 receptor

Uses

FDA approved

  • Long-term management of psychosis and schizophrenia
  • Maintenance therapy in mania bipolar disorder
  • Management of irritability in autism spectrum disorder

 

Off label uses

  • Management of psychosis in delirium and dementia (Option B)
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorders (Option A)
  • PTSD (Option C)

Adverse effects
  • Hyperprolactinemia
  • Cardiovascular accident
  • Extrapyramidal side effects

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs can also be used to treat neuropathic pain? Pregabalin Carbamazepine Lamotrigine Gabapentin
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism of Action

Uses

Side Effects

Carbamazepine

Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.

Trigeminal neuralgia

GTCS, partial seizures, bipolar disorder.

Sedation, dizziness, ataxia, GI disturbances, bone marrow suppression, hypersensitivity reactions, water retention.

Gabapentin

Enhances GABA release modulates voltage-sensitive Ca2+ channels.

Partial seizures, post-herpetic neuralgia,

Peripheral neuropathy migraine prophylaxis

Sedation, tiredness, dizziness, tremor, unsteadiness.

Pregabalin

Selectively binds to the α2-δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels and reduces glutamate release.

Diabetic neuropathy, Post-herpetic neuralgia, Fibromyalgia and Spinal cord injury.

questions.text: Topiramate is used for which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

Topiramate

MOA
  • Reduces voltage-gated sodium currents in cerebellar granule cells.
  • Activated hyperpolarising potassium current, which enhances GABA-A receptor
  • Limits the activation of AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.
  • Modulationof the activity of GABA and glutamate

Uses

  • Focal and primary generalized epilepsy
  • Refractory focal epilepsy
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS)
  • Prophylaxis of migraine
  • Obesity

Pharmacokinetics

  • 20% is bound to plasma proteins
  • Excreted in urine unchanged with a t1/2 of 24 hours
  • Enzyme activation occurs

Adverse effects

  • Somnolence, weight loss, fatigue, nervousness
  • Renal calculi formation
  • Cognitive impairment

questions.text: Which drug is most likely responsible for visual disturbances and contraction of the visual field in a patient who was taking antiepileptics for seizure management?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Vigabatrin

Drug

Ophthalmic side effects

Vigabatrin

Significant risk of permanent peripheral visual field defects (visual field constriction) and retinal toxicity.

Topiramate

Potential for acute myopia, secondary angle-closure glaucoma, and visual disturbances such as blurred vision and diplopia.

Serum lithium (mEq/L)

Mild

Moderate

Confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, hypertonia

Severe

Seizures, hyperthermia, hypotension, Coma

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Tolcapone

Tolcapone

MOA

It inhibits the catechol-o-methyl transferase enzyme, which is responsible for the breakdown of catecholamines, which prolongs the action of catechols in the CNS and peripheral tissue.

Uses

Adjunct therapy in Parkinson’s disease.

Side effects

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • On/Off phenomenon

Neurological Symptoms:

  • Dyskinesia (due to increased levodopa bioavailability)
  • Dizziness
  • Headache
  • Sleep disturbances (e.g., insomnia)

Psychiatric Symptoms:

  • Hallucinations
  • Confusion
  • Increased impulsive behaviors

What is the medication utilized for the treatment of refractory and intractable rheumatic chorea?
questions.explanation:
Epileptics uses 

Non - epileptic uses 

Drug of choice:

  • GTCS
  • Myoclonic and absence seizures
  • Lennox Gastaut syndrome 
  • Dravet syndrome

questions.text: A psychiatrist prescribes lithium for a patient who is diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding lithium?

options.label: A
options.text: Lithium is teratogenic if given to pregnant females

options.label: B
options.text: Lithium toxicity is exacerbated with thiazide

options.label: C
options.text: Lithium can decrease thyroid hormone levels

options.label: D
options.text: Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose

Lithium

Mechanism of action

  • Increase the level of amine (if the mood is low) by inhibiting the Glycogen synthase kinase-3 enzyme
  • Decrease the level of amine (if the mood is high)
    • Inhibits inositol monophosphatase enzyme
    • Inhibits the release of amines
    • Stabilises neuronal membrane

Uses

  • Bipolar disorder
  • Hypnic headache (occurs in sleep)
  • Anti-suicidal action (another drug is clozapine)
  • Resistant cases of depression

Adverse effects
  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect (Option A) when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes modulation of voltage-gated sodium channels by selectively enhancing slow inactivation?
Which anti-epileptic drug is commonly associated with gum hypertrophy and dizziness as side effects?

A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of blurred vision, dizziness, and severe headache after ingesting an unknown quantity of homemade alcohol earlier in the day. On examination, he is disoriented. Laboratory tests reveal severe metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. Which metabolite is primarily responsible for the toxicity in this case?
questions.explanation:
• Adulteration in Country liquor.
  • Solvent in industrial processes.
  • Antifreeze.

Mechanism of Action
  • Methanol ö Formaldehyde (oxidation by alcohol dehydrogenase).
  • Formaldehyde ö Formic acid (oxidation by aldehyde dehydrogenase).
  • Formic Acid ö Inhibition of Cytochrome c Oxidase ö Cellular Hypoxia and Metabolic Acidosis.

Features of Toxicity
  • CNS: Headache, dizziness, confusion, ataxia, seizures
  • Ocular: Blurred ("snowfield" vision).
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, fruity breath and abdominal pain
  • Metabolic: Severe metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap

Treatment

Mnemonic: SHAFE

  • Sodium Bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis to remove methanol and its metabolites
  • Antidote: Fomepizole or Ethanol to inhibit ADH
  • Folinic acid or folic acid to enhance formate metabolism.

questions.text: A patient was given an antipsychotic drug, haloperidol and the patient developed acute dystonia. Which is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Extrapyramidal Symptoms

Condition

Onset

Treatment

Acute muscle Dystonia

Within 1-5 days of starting antipsychotic

Administering antiparkinsonian agents such as diphenhydramine or benztropine intramuscularly.

Parkinsonism

Within 1 month

Benzhexol and benztropine (NOT Levodopa)

Akathisia

(Most common EPS)

5–60 days

Anti-anxiety medications

  1. DOC: Propranolol (C/I: Asthma)
  2. Diazepam

Rabbit Syndrome

Months or years
  1. Antiparkinsonian agents.
  2. Amantadine is preferred due to less adverse cognitive effects.

Tardive Dyskinesia

Late-onset adverse effects (after months or years)

Occurs due to D2 receptor supersensitivity and can be permanent, even after discontinuing antipsychotic medication.

Stop AP drugs & start Clozapine.

If symptoms persist, add Dopamine depleters (VMAT2 inhibitors)

  1. Valbenazine
  2. Tetrabenazine: DOC for Huntington's disease.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Ethosuximide?

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibits calcium channels in thalamic neurons

questions.correct_answer: B. Inhibits calcium channels in thalamic neurons
questions.explanation:
Ethosuximide

MOA

Primarily blocks T type of calcium channel

Uses

Only used in absence seizures

Advantages

It is not hepatotoxic

Side effects
  • Bone marrow suppression
  • SLE - like symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following is the half-life of lithium in adults?
questions.explanation:
Pharmacokinetics of Lithium

Salt

Lithium carbonate or citrate.

Route of administration

Oral or IV

Half-life
  • Healthy adults: 24 hours.
  • Young: 12 hrs in the young
  • Older: 36 hours in the elderly (or longer due to a reduced GFR).

Metabolism

It is not metabolized in the body; it remains unchanged in the system.

Excretion

Excreted unchanged in all body secretions

  • Maximum in the urine
  • Sweat, saliva and breast milk

questions.text: A 35-year male patient presents to surgery emergency with painful erection for the past 7 hours. He has a history of mood disorder and was recently prescribed medication by treating psychiatrist. Which is the likely offending drug?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - T

questions.text: Which is a rare but very serious side effect of clozapine that requires regular monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

Serious Adverse Effects of Clozapine

Agranulocytosis
  • Rare but life-threatening decrease in white blood cells, requiring weekly monitoring.
  • Discontinue if total leukocyte count < 3000/mm³ or absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm³.
  • Avoid combining with carbamazepine.
  • Monitoring of agranulocytosis: 1st 6 weeks - weekly; Next 6 months- Fortnightly; After 1 year- Monthly

Seizures
  • Dose-dependent seizure risk. Higher than other atypical antipsychotics.

Cardiac Effects
  • Risk of tachycardia, myocarditis (fatal, within first 6 wks) and dilated cardiomyopathy.

Non-serious Adverse effects of Clozapine

Hypersalivation

  • Known as "wet pillow syndrome" due to muscarinic receptor stimulation.

Metabolic Complications
  • Significant risk of weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia.
  • Associated with increased appetite due to 5-HT2C receptor blockade.

Cataracts
  • Higher risk than other atypical antipsychotics.

Effects on Pregnancy and Breastfeeding
  • Can cause decreased arousal and hypotonia in neonates.
  • C/I during breastfeeding due to the risk of neutropenia, sedation, and seizures in infants.

questions.text: A patient underwent a hysterectomy and was given morphine in the post-operative period and in the ward for pain. She now presents with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils. What is the drug used to treat this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Naloxone

Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose.

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote) → Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine → Abstinence (Prevent relapse):
  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in diabetic neuropathy, post herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Pregabalin

questions.text: Sodium valproate has an inhibitory action at which of the following sites?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - B

Sodium Valproate

Mechanism of Action
  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

Uses

  • Seizure Disorders: It is the DOC for atypical absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome.

Adverse Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Drug interactions

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin

questions.text: A patient on amitriptyline was found in an unconscious state. Which of the following does not suggest amitriptyline toxicity?

Correct Answer C - Hypothermia

Mechanism of side effect

Side effect

H1 receptor blockade
  • Sedation, weight gain

Anticholinergic action on muscarinic receptors
  • Hyperthermia (Option C)
  • Dry eyes/mouth
  • Mydriasis (C/I in glaucoma) (Option D)
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Tachycardia
  • Confusion (Option B)

Increase in serotonin in the brain
  • Seizure threshold reduction

Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor antagonism
  • Postural hypotension

Sodium channel block
  • Arrhythmia/QT prolongation (Option A)
  • Bradycardia in heart block due to overdose

questions.text: What is the most common side effect of Lamotrigine ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Rash

Drug class

Antiepileptic

Mechanism of action

Voltage-gated sodium channel blocker

Indications

  • Partial seizures, generalized seizures, bipolar disorder

  • DOC for focal seizures elderly

Dosage forms

Tablets, chewable tablets, orally disintegrating tablets

Dosage

Varies depending on the condition being treated and other factors; usually started at a low dose and gradually increased over several weeks

Common side effects

Rash, headache, nausea, dizziness, blurred vision

Serious side effects

  • Steven Johnson Syndrome (skin surface <30%)

  • Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (skin surface >30%)

questions.text: Among the subsequent atypical antipsychotic medications, which one poses the greatest likelihood of galactorrhea?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - R

questions.text: Antidote for alprazolam is:
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Flu

questions.text: Secretion of prolactin is inhibited by ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - D

questions.text: Anti-depressant drug which is used for smoking cessation is ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Bupropion:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with symptoms of decreased sleep, increased activity levels, and an elevated mood. He also has a family history of manic episodes. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Lithiu

questions.text: Which of the following is used as an antidote in opioid overdose?
questions.explanation: Correct option A:

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drug is least teratogenic during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct option D: Lev

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug has the lowest risk of causing birth defects during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Lev

questions.text: Which anti-amoebic medication, when combined with alcohol, may have caused the lady to experience symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and dizziness at a social gathering?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - M

questions.text: Chlorpromazine acts on which of the following receptor? 1) D2 and 5-HT2 receptor 2) GABA and beta - adrenergic receptor 3) Muscarinic M1 and alpha - adrenergic receptors 4) H1 receptors
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - 1, 3 and 4
